ygData.subject: Re: How would novelty search best be applied to a virtual creature controller
ygData.msgSnippet: Rafael, What you are saying is true -- if you are interested in finding a specific behavior with novelty search, then you need to design the novelty measure so

From: "joel278" <lehman.154@...>
Subject: Re: How would novelty search best be applied to a virtual creature controller
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=130984297; y=Ei4xjglqlImnNV2SremJL4o4GObMUNT3o_fn4EZzYg1KjBTzBemr
X-Yahoo-Profile: joel278

Rafael,

What you are saying is true -- if you are interested in finding a
=
specific behavior with novelty search, then you need to design the
novelty =
measure so that the behavior of interest is distinct from
other behaviors. =
If the goal behavior is not differentiated from
initial behaviors than perf=
ormance will likely be poor, because any
navigator that came close to the g=
oal behavior would be *penalized* by
novelty search rather than rewarded (s=
ince this behavior would not be
seen as novel).

So the novelty metric is v=
ery important when it comes to biasing the
search, and should "recognize" t=
he goal behavior and not conflate it
with non-goal behaviors.

For example,=
 in the maze navigation domain, if the novelty measure was
"how much does a=
 navigator rotate during an evaluation", then we would
expect to find navig=
ators with various spinning behaviors, but there
is no reason to expect nav=
igators to fully navigate the maze; that is
because rotation is not correla=
ted with any exploratory movement
within the maze. In addition, a navigator=
 that reached the goal (and
rotated x degrees while doing so) would appear =
the same as a navigator
that sat at the initial location and spun x degrees=
.

This goal/non-goal conflation is an example of harmful conflation, and
a=
 way of combating it is to simply provide more information (or more
relevan=
t information) in the behavioral characterization of an
individual. It is n=
ot always obvious what the most relevant
information is for a given domain,=
 e.g. in biped walking, although one
can usually make an informed hypothesi=
s - for example, the final
location of a biped walker after an evaluation m=
ay differentiate
a successful walker from a biped that cannot walk (because=
 a
successful walker will travel further), whereas using the angle of a
bip=
ed's head as a novelty measure will probably not be effective since
head an=
gle probably has no relation to behaviors of interest.

However, I don't th=
ink it is accurate to say that the objective
function is embedded within no=
velty search; novelty search searches
only for novel behaviors, ignoring an=
y notion of better and worse with
respect to the goal. I think what you are=
 saying is that you still
have to have some criteria for termination (i.e. =
a routine that
recognizes a successful individual). 

It is important to di=
fferentiate an objective function that provides a
gradient towards *better*=
 individuals that is used in typical
approaches from a binary "have we foun=
d the goal yet" function that
does not actively bias the search. One of the=
 key arguments in the
paper is that the bias of the objective function ofte=
n keeps search
from reaching the goal.

Joel

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, =
"Rafael C.P." <kurama.youko.br@...> wrote:
>
> But didn't the agent reached=
 the goal just because the goal is very
> different from the start position=
? It's like the objective function was
> embedded in the novelty function. =
If the goal was similar to the start
> position in novelty space, it probab=
ly would perform worse than random
> search. But anyway, I think the agent =
couldn't stop searching by
itself when
> reached the goal unless you told h=
im to stop there, 'cause he would
still
> try novel behaviors after that.
>=
 
> On Wed, May 14, 2008 at 2:39 PM, Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...>
> wrote=
:
> 
> >   Peter, there is no indication that the maze solvers produced by
=
> > novelty search are any less "smart" than those produced by
> > fitness-=
based search. As we mention in the paper briefly under
> > "Typical Solutio=
n," solutions from both methods just go straight to
> > the goal. In other =
words, they do not take meandering paths; they
> > take the most rational p=
ath and appear goal-oriented. So there is no
> > discernible quality differ=
ence.
> >
> > However, it's an interesting issue because it gets to the que=
stion of
> > what it means to be smart vs. lucky. In general, if an animal =
has a
> > behavior that gets the job done consistently, one could say the a=
nimal
> > just "happens" to do the right thing, or one could say the animal=
 is
> > "smart." In fact, I think these are one and the same and the
> > di=
stinction does not really add insight into the inner workings
> > of the an=
imal's mind.
> >
> > One of the reasons we get stuck on the issue of whethe=
r something is
> > "really" smart is because of the allure of the adaptive =
hypothesis in
> > evolutionary theory: We try to explain everything we see =
in nature in
> > terms of some kind of adaptation, and as soon as you assum=
e that what
> > you are seeing is the result of an adaptation, you are susc=
eptible to
> > the idea that it must be "good" in some way (which equates t=
o "smart"
> > when decision-making is at issue). Yet what novelty search sh=
ows is
> > that a non-adaptive process can in many cases produce equivalent=

> > behaviors, which really turns the adaptive hypothesis upside-down, and=

> > makes the interpretation of the "value" of a behavior more confusing.
=
> > Yet at the end of the day, if it works it works, regardless of why it
>=
 > became the way it did.
> >
> > Anyway, so on the question of time series=
, I would not be concerned
> > with this issue of whether it is really smar=
t. However, another
> > consideration is whether there is sufficient domain=
 constraint to make
> > this search something other than exhaustive enumera=
tion. Novelty
> > search relies on the properties of the domain (i.e. the e=
nvironment)
> > to create a useful landscape for the search. Something with=
out any
> > environmental constraint may not make a good search space. So f=
or
> > example searching through all possible pictures hoping to find Mona
=
> > Lisa one day may not be a good idea because just about anything you do
=
> > genetically produces something "novel." In other words, there is no
> >=
 "collapse" of multiple genetic points into fewer novelty points (or
> > mo=
re accurately, there may not be cases of novelty points clustered
> > close=
r together in behavior space than the corresponding genomes in
> > genome s=
pace).
> >
> > Still, I am not sure about time series, because the distribu=
tion of
> > input precursor series may be thought of as a kind of constrain=
t,
> > since there are some precursor series you would never see. So it may=

> > actually work...I'm not sure, but it's an interesting possibility.
> >=

> >
> > ken
> >
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com <neat%40yahoogroups.com>,

behaviors, right. But are

 the robot in the 2D maze
> > > experiment succeed just because of luck? It=
 is possible that a
> > > behavior that appears a solution to be discovered=
, but the robot
acts

accident? How much
> > > this depends upon the environment and the inputs p=
rovided? Is it the
> > > same with fitness-based search? I am asking this b=
ecause I am about
> > > to introduce novelty search to time series forecast=
ing which is very
> > > complex domain in terms of characterizing behavior.=

> > >
> > > Peter

ost ANN models. The leaky integrators are better for precise

> > > > However, they may not be necessary if joint angles are being

provided
> > > > as input. But when joint angles are not provided, I do not=
 think I
> > > > have ever seen a regular recurrent ANN (i.e. non-leaky or =
not some
> > > > other special type of neuron) be able to make something wa=
lk. In
> > > > fact, the "flailing" motions are often reduced significantly=
 by
> > > leaky
> > > > integrator neurons. Tyler Streeter saw this when he=
 worked on his
> > > > biped with NEAT, which actually stopped flailing aft=
er
switching to
> > > > leaky integrators. However, in his project the netw=
ork had no
> > > inputs
> > > > and worked entirely through internal patter=
n generation.
> > > >

> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > Hi Peter,=
 that's a good question and of course learning to
> > > > > control a
> > >=
 > > > > virtual creature with novelty search is a complicated issue
> > > =
(and
> > > > > an
> > > > > > > appealing idea as well).
> > > > > > >
> > =
> > > > > First, you have to deal with all the representational and
> > > >=
 > physical
> > > > > > > issues outside of novelty search, like how many i=
nputs, how
> > > many
> > > > > > > outputs, and whether the body itself is=
 not physically
flawed
> > > in
> > > > > > > some way (which is possible).=
 As you are experiencing, the
> > > > > > > inputs/outputs issue can be pro=
hibitive even with feature
> > > > > > > selection. It is also possible tha=
t HyperNEAT could be
> > > useful
> > > > > > > because it does not care ab=
out the # inputs or outputs (and
> > > can
> > > > > > > potentially exploi=
t geometric regularities), but configuring
> > > the
> > > > > > > substrat=
e then becomes the challenge.
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > Assuming all of t=
hat stuff is set up well with whatever
> > > system,
> > > > > then
> > > >=
 > > > novelty search is a potentially winning approach. Yet as you
> > > >=
 > point
> > > > > > > out there are some big questions there as well. In f=
act, we
> > > are
> > > > > > > currently trying to provide the best answer=
s to these
> > > questions
> > > > > in
> > > > > > > ongoing research, but=
 some general principles might help for
> > > now:
> > > > > > >
> > > > > =
> > First, the archive in novelty search does not not need to
> > > contain=

> > > > > > > every point ever visited. Therefore, it tends to grow much
>=
 > > > > slower
> > > > > > > than the #of evaluations. However, if it is i=
ndeed getting
> > > too
> > > > > big
> > > > > > > then it is not unreason=
able to collapse some of the archive
> > > > > points,
> > > > > > > althou=
gh there is no standard method yet for how that should
> > > be
> > > > > >=
 > done. But we have reason to believe there will be effective
> > > and
> =
> > > > > > simple ways to do that.
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > Second, the=
 issue of one individual looking different just
> > > > > because
> > > > >=
 > > of a phase difference in effectivley the same behavior is
> > > > > > =
> complicated. For certain phase disaparities, the two
> > > individuals
> =
> > > > > > won't look all that different, but it is true that at some
> > =
> > > > > disparity, they may look very different. Yet it is not clear
> > =
> > > > > whether that fact is actually problematic to the novelty
> > > se=
arch
> > > > > or
> > > > > > > not, because it would simply reward both ty=
pes of behavior.
> > > It
> > > > > is
> > > > > > > possible that the phas=
e difference is a result of some
useful
> > > > > > > genotypic change, whi=
ch could make it a stepping stone to
> > > > > something
> > > > > > > bett=
er. Or, it is possible that it is superfluous
> > > information
> > > > > a=
nd
> > > > > > > simply takes some extra time exploring the area around the=

> > > phase-
> > > > > > > shifted individual. So it is hard to say a prio=
ri whether it
> > > is
> > > > > a
> > > > > > > major concern. We will hav=
e better answers to such questions
> > > as
> > > > > the
> > > > > > > tec=
hnique is further explored.
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > However, I agree th=
at it would be nice to be able to say the
> > > two
> > > > > > > phase-shi=
fted individuals are largely the same if that is
> > > indeed
> > > > > > >=
 what you want to say. And for that, you would need a
pattern-
> > > > > > =
> matching metric to compute behavioral distance, i.e.
> > > something
> > =
> > > more
> > > > > > > sophisiticated than simple Cartesian distance. The=
re are
> > > > > certainly
> > > > > > > such metrics available. However, i=
t's important to recognize
> > > > > that
> > > > > > > it is not evident a=
t this point that ignoring the phase
shift
> > > is
> > > > > > > actually =
better than taking it into consideration, because
> > > taking
> > > > > it=

> > > > > > > into consideration just means adding more information to the=

> > > > > novelty
> > > > > > > landscape.
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > So =
overall I think novelty search is a very promising
> > > direction
> > > > =
> to
> > > > > > > go for such problems, but it is still in the realm of
> =
> > research
> > > > > (i.e.
> > > > > > > there is no existing precedent),=
 so it will involve
> > > considerable
> > > > > > > trial and error to get=
 it right until all these issues are
> > > > > fleshed
> > > > > > > out mo=
re clearly. Ultimately, though, if our hypothesis
> > > about
> > > > > > >=
 novelty vs. fitness is correct, novelty search may turn out
> > > to be
> =
> > > > > > the *only* way to get certain highly complex types of
> > > beh=
avior to
> > > > > > > evolve in some domains, which is a sobering thought.=
 But if
> > > it
> > > > > is
> > > > > > > true, then there is not much to=
 do other than try it.

ses the open dynamics engine for physics, like breve.

ly, I would like to package AI's with the Toribash
> > > game
> > > > > so

think=

> > > > > > > goal
> > > > > > > > is attainable despite be=
ing difficult.

ss criteria is
> > > time
> > > > > > > > integrated distance from a goal, =
it encourages the
> > > behaviour of
> > > > > the
> > > > > > > > "Tori" b=
alancing in a stable configuration forever, rather
> > > than
> > > > > > >=
 > walking, which is what I'm trying to encourage. As
there is
> > > 20
> >=
 > > > > > joints
> > > > > > > > in this rig, I am providing joint positio=
n and velocity
> > > > > information
> > > > > > > > for each joint, as wel=
l as a bias, a sine-wave, the x, y,
> > > and z
> > > > > > > > components =
linear velocity in the reference frame of the
> > > Tori's
> > > > > > > he=
ad,
> > > > > > > > and finally 3 variables which correspond to the vertica=
l,
> > > > > > > horizontal
> > > > > > > > and forward orientation of the =
tori's head with respect to
> > > world
> > > > > > > > coordinates.
> > > =
> > > > > The current experimental configuration I am started out as
> > > =
> > a "pure"
> > > > > > > > ragdoll control where neural net outputs corre=
spond
> > > directly
> > > > > joint
> > > > > > > > velocity; a tanh activ=
ation function is used to allow
> > > positive
> > > > > and
> > > > > > > =
> negative joint movement.
> > > > > > > > I then remodeled the experiment =
to perform as in the
> > > Toribash
> > > > > game;
> > > > > > > > the net=
 will receive inputs (and effect joint movements)
> > > only
> > > > > > > =
every 10
> > > > > > > > time steps. More importantly, I increased the amou=
nt of
> > > outputs
> > > > > > > from
> > > > > > > > 20 (1 per joint) to =
40, in order to accomodate the 4
> > > possible
> > > > > joint
> > > > > >=
 > > actions which can occur on a turn: holding, relaxing,
> > > > > extend=
ing,
> > > > > > > and
> > > > > > > > flexing.
> > > > > > > >
> > > > > >=
 > > Starting with a fully connected net, that gives a
> > > staggeringly
>=
 > > > > huge
